Given: xy'+y=0 and y(2)=2.  If you substitute y=k×x^n (supposing the solution has this form), you get x×n×x^(n-1) + x^n =0. And this must be true for all values of x. If this were true then clearly n=-1. So if our supposition about the form were true then the solution is of the form k/x. Since y(2)=2 we get k/2=2 => k=4. So a solution to the differential equation and the extra condition is y=4/x.
